# Mars Exploration Rover

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the mission that launched in 2003. For the Mars rover
that landed in 2012, see [Curiosity (rover)](/wiki/Curiosity_\(rover\)
"Curiosity \(rover\)"). For the generic topic, see [Mars
rover](/wiki/Mars_rover "Mars rover").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/NASA_Mars_Rover.jpg/300px-
NASA_Mars_Rover.jpg)](/wiki/File:NASA_Mars_Rover.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NASA_Mars_Rover.jpg "Enlarge")

Artist's conception of rover on Mars

[NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA")'s **Mars Exploration Rover** (**MER**) mission is an
ongoing [robotic space mission](/wiki/Robotic_space_mission "Robotic space
mission") involving two [Mars rovers](/wiki/Mars_rover "Mars rover"),
_**Spirit**_[1] and _**Opportunity**_ ,[2] exploring the planet
[Mars](/wiki/Mars "Mars"). It began in 2003 with the launch of the two
[rovers](/wiki/Rover_\(space_exploration\) "Rover \(space exploration\)"):
MER-A _[Spirit](/wiki/Spirit_\(rover\) "Spirit \(rover\)")_ and MER-B
_[Opportunity](/wiki/Opportunity_\(rover\) "Opportunity \(rover\)")_ —to
explore the Martian surface and [geology](/wiki/Geology_of_Mars "Geology of
Mars"); both landed on Mars at separate locations in January 2004. Both rovers
far outlived their planned missions of 90 [Martian solar
days](/wiki/Timekeeping_on_Mars#Sols "Timekeeping on Mars"): MER-A
_[Spirit](/wiki/Spirit_\(rover\) "Spirit \(rover\)")_ was active until 2010,
while MER-B _[Opportunity](/wiki/Opportunity_\(rover\) "Opportunity
\(rover\)")_ is still active in 2018, and holds the record for the longest
distance driven by any off-Earth wheeled vehicle.

##
Objectives[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Objectives")]

The mission's scientific objective was to search for and characterize a wide
range of [rocks](/wiki/Rock_\(geology\) "Rock \(geology\)") and
[soils](/wiki/Soil "Soil") that hold clues to past water activity on Mars. The
mission is part of NASA's [Mars Exploration
Program](/wiki/Mars_Exploration_Program "Mars Exploration Program"), which
includes three previous successful landers: the two [Viking
program](/wiki/Viking_program "Viking program") landers in 1976 and [Mars
Pathfinder](/wiki/Mars_Pathfinder "Mars Pathfinder") probe in 1997.[3]

The total cost of building, launching, landing and operating the rovers on the
surface for the initial 90-[sol](/wiki/Martian_day#Sols "Martian day") primary
mission was US$820 million.[4] Since the rovers have continued to function
beyond their initial 90 sol primary mission, they have each received five
mission extensions. The fifth mission extension was granted in October 2007,
and ran to the end of 2009.[4][5] The total cost of the first four mission
extensions was $104 million, and the fifth mission extension is expected to
cost at least $20 million.[4]

In July 2007, during the fourth mission extension, Martian dust storms blocked
sunlight to the rovers and threatened the ability of the craft to gather
energy through their [solar panels](/wiki/Solar_panel "Solar panel"), causing
engineers to fear that one or both of them might be permanently disabled.
However, the dust storms lifted, allowing them to resume operations.[6]

On May 1, 2009, during its fifth mission extension, _Spirit_ became stuck in
soft soil on Mars.[7] After nearly nine months of attempts to get the rover
back on track, including using test rovers on Earth, NASA announced on January
26, 2010 that _Spirit_ was being retasked as a stationary science platform.
This mode would enable _Spirit_ to assist scientists in ways that a mobile
platform could not, such as detecting "[wobbles](/wiki/Chandler_wobble
"Chandler wobble")" in the planet's rotation that would indicate a liquid
core.[8] Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) lost contact with Spirit after last
hearing from the rover on March 22, 2010 and continued attempts to regain
communications lasted until May 25, 2011, bringing the elapsed mission time to
6 years 2 months 19 days, or over 25 times the original planned mission
duration.[9]

In recognition of the vast amount of [scientific
information](/wiki/Scientific_information_from_the_Mars_Exploration_Rover_mission
"Scientific information from the Mars Exploration Rover mission") amassed by
both rovers, two [asteroids](/wiki/Asteroid "Asteroid") have been named in
their honor: [37452 Spirit](/wiki/37452_Spirit "37452 Spirit") and [39382
Opportunity](/wiki/39382_Opportunity "39382 Opportunity"). The mission is
managed for [NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA") by the [Jet Propulsion
Laboratory](/wiki/Jet_Propulsion_Laboratory "Jet Propulsion Laboratory"),
which designed, built, and is operating the rovers.

On January 24, 2014, NASA reported that current studies by the remaining
[rover](/wiki/Mars_rover "Mars rover")
[_Opportunity_](/wiki/Opportunity_\(rover\) "Opportunity \(rover\)") as well
as by the newer [Mars Science Laboratory](/wiki/Mars_Science_Laboratory "Mars
Science Laboratory") rover [_Curiosity_](/wiki/Curiosity_\(rover\) "Curiosity
\(rover\)") will now be searching for evidence of ancient life, including a
[biosphere](/wiki/Biosphere "Biosphere") based on
[autotrophic](/wiki/Autotroph "Autotroph"), [chemotrophic](/wiki/Chemotroph
"Chemotroph") and/or [chemolithoautotrophic](/wiki/Lithotroph#Chemolithotrophs
"Lithotroph") [microorganisms](/wiki/Microorganism "Microorganism"), as well
as ancient water, including [fluvio-lacustrine
environments](/wiki/Lacustrine_plain "Lacustrine plain") ([plains](/wiki/Plain
"Plain") related to ancient rivers or lakes) that may have been
[habitable](/wiki/Planetary_habitability "Planetary
habitability").[10][11][12][13] The search for evidence of
[habitability](/wiki/Planetary_habitability "Planetary habitability"),
[taphonomy](/wiki/Taphonomy "Taphonomy") (related to [fossils](/wiki/Fossils
"Fossils")), and [organic carbon](/wiki/Organic_carbon "Organic carbon") on
the planet [Mars](/wiki/Mars "Mars") is now a primary [NASA](/wiki/NASA
"NASA") objective.[10]

The scientific objectives of the Mars Exploration Rover mission are to:[14]

  * Search for and characterize a variety of rocks and soils that hold clues to past [water](/wiki/Water_on_Mars "Water on Mars") activity. In particular, samples sought include those that have minerals deposited by water-related processes such as [precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation_\(meteorology\) "Precipitation \(meteorology\)"), [evaporation](/wiki/Water_vapor "Water vapor"), [sedimentary cementation](/wiki/Sedimentary_rock "Sedimentary rock"), or [hydrothermal activity](/wiki/Hydrothermal_activity "Hydrothermal activity").
  * Determine the distribution and composition of minerals, rocks, and soils surrounding the landing sites.
  * Determine what [geologic processes](/wiki/Geology_of_Mars "Geology of Mars") have shaped the local terrain and influenced the chemistry. Such processes could include water or wind erosion, sedimentation, hydrothermal mechanisms, volcanism, and cratering.
  * Perform calibration and validation of surface observations made by [Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter](/wiki/Mars_Reconnaissance_Orbiter "Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter") instruments. This will help determine the accuracy and effectiveness of various instruments that survey Martian geology from orbit.
  * Search for iron-containing minerals, and to identify and quantify relative amounts of specific mineral types that contain water or were formed in water, such as iron-bearing carbonates.
  * Characterize the [mineralogy](/wiki/Mineralogy "Mineralogy") and textures of rocks and soils to determine the processes that created them.
  * Search for geological clues to the [environmental conditions](/wiki/Environmental_science "Environmental science") that existed when liquid water was present.
  * Assess whether those environments were conducive to [life](/wiki/Life "Life").

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Lancement_Spirit_fusee_Delta_IIs_10062003.jpg/145px-
Lancement_Spirit_fusee_Delta_IIs_10062003.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lancement_Spirit_fusee_Delta_IIs_10062003.jpg)

Launch of MER-A Spirit

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Mer-b-final-
launch.jpg/147px-Mer-b-final-launch.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mer-b-final-launch.jpg)

Launch of MER-B Opportunity

The [MER-A](/wiki/Spirit_\(rover\) "Spirit \(rover\)") and
[MER-B](/wiki/Opportunity_\(rover\) "Opportunity \(rover\)") probes were
launched on June 10, 2003 and July 7, 2003, respectively. Though both probes
launched on [Boeing](/wiki/Boeing "Boeing") [Delta II](/wiki/Delta_II "Delta
II") 7925-9.5 rockets from [Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch
Complex 17](/wiki/Cape_Canaveral_Air_Force_Station_Space_Launch_Complex_17
"Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17") (CCAFS SLC-17),
MER-B was on the heavy version of that launch vehicle, needing the extra
energy for [Trans-Mars injection](/wiki/Trans-Mars_injection "Trans-Mars
injection"). The launch vehicles were integrated onto pads right next to each
other,[15] with MER-A on CCAFS SLC-17A and MER-B on CCAFS SLC-17B. The dual
pads allowed for working the 15- and 21-day planetary launch periods close
together; the last possible launch day for MER-A was June 19, 2003 and the
first day for MER-B was June 25, 2003. [NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA")'s [Launch
Services Program](/wiki/Launch_Services_Program "Launch Services Program")
managed the launch of both spacecraft.

The probes landed in January 2004 in widely separated equatorial locations on
Mars.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/MER_Timeline_English_2014.png/300px-
MER_Timeline_English_2014.png)](/wiki/File:MER_Timeline_English_2014.png)

[](/wiki/File:MER_Timeline_English_2014.png "Enlarge")

Timeline of the Mars Exploration mission

On January 21, 2004, the [Deep Space Network](/wiki/Deep_Space_Network "Deep
Space Network") lost contact with _Spirit_ , for reasons originally thought to
be related to a [thunderstorm](/wiki/Thunderstorm "Thunderstorm") over
[Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"). The rover transmitted a message with
no data, but later that day missed another communications session with the
[Mars Global Surveyor](/wiki/Mars_Global_Surveyor "Mars Global Surveyor"). The
next day, [JPL](/wiki/JPL "JPL") received a beep from the rover, indicating
that it was in fault mode. On January 23, the flight team succeeded in making
the rover send. The fault was believed to have been caused by an error in the
rover's [flash memory](/wiki/Flash_memory "Flash memory") subsystem. The rover
did not perform any scientific activities for ten days, while engineers
updated its software and ran tests. The problem was corrected by reformatting
_Spirit '_s flash memory and using a [software patch](/wiki/Software_patch
"Software patch") to avoid memory overload; _Opportunity_ was also upgraded
with the patch as a precaution. _Spirit_ returned to full scientific
operations by February 5.

On March 23, 2004, a news conference was held announcing "major discoveries"
of evidence of past liquid water on the Martian surface. A delegation of
scientists showed pictures and data revealing a stratified pattern and [cross
bedding](/wiki/Cross_bedding "Cross bedding") in the rocks of the outcrop
inside a crater in [Meridiani Planum](/wiki/Meridiani_Planum "Meridiani
Planum"), landing site of [MER-B, _Opportunity_](/wiki/MER-B "MER-B"). This
suggested that water once flowed in the region. The irregular distribution of
[chlorine](/wiki/Chlorine "Chlorine") and [bromine](/wiki/Bromine "Bromine")
also suggests that the place was once the shoreline of a salty sea, now
evaporated.

On April 8, 2004, NASA announced that it was extending the mission life of the
rovers from three to eight months. It immediately provided additional funding
of US $15 million through September, and $2.8 million per month for continuing
operations. Later that month, _Opportunity_ arrived at [Endurance
crater](/wiki/Endurance_\(crater\) "Endurance \(crater\)"), taking about five
days to drive the 200 meters. NASA announced on September 22 that it was
extending the mission life of the rovers for another six months. _Opportunity_
was to leave Endurance crater, visit its discarded heat shield, and proceed to
[Victoria crater](/wiki/Victoria_\(crater\) "Victoria \(crater\)"). _Spirit_
was to attempt to climb to the top of the [Columbia
Hills](/wiki/Columbia_Hills_\(Mars\) "Columbia Hills \(Mars\)").

With the two rovers still functioning well, NASA later announced another
18-month extension of the mission to September 2006. _Opportunity_ was to
visit the "Etched Terrain" and _Spirit_ was to climb a rocky slope toward the
top of [Husband Hill](/wiki/Husband_Hill "Husband Hill"). On August 21, 2005,
_Spirit_ reached the summit of Husband Hill after 581
[sols](/wiki/Timekeeping_on_Mars#Sols "Timekeeping on Mars") and a journey of
4.81 kilometers (2.99 mi).

_Spirit_ celebrated its one Martian year anniversary (669 sols or 687 Earth
days) on November 20, 2005. _Opportunity_ celebrated its anniversary on
December 12, 2005. At the beginning of the mission, it was expected that the
rovers would not survive much longer than 90 Martian days. The Columbia Hills
were "just a dream", according to rover driver Chris Leger. _Spirit_ explored
the semicircular rock formation known as [Home
Plate](/wiki/Home_Plate_\(Mars\) "Home Plate \(Mars\)"). It is a layered rock
outcrop that puzzles and excites scientists.[16] It is thought that its rocks
are explosive volcanic deposits, though other possibilities exist, including
impact deposits or sediment borne by wind or water.

_Spirit 's_ front right wheel ceased working on March 13, 2006, while the
rover was moving itself to [McCool Hill](/wiki/McCool_Hill "McCool Hill"). Its
drivers attempted to drag the dead wheel behind Spirit, but this only worked
until reaching an impassable sandy area on the lower slopes. Drivers directed
_Spirit_ to a smaller sloped feature, dubbed "Low Ridge Haven", where it spent
the long Martian winter, waiting for spring and increased solar power levels
suitable for driving. That September, _Opportunity_ reached the rim of
[Victoria crater](/wiki/Victoria_crater "Victoria crater"), and Spaceflight
Now reported that NASA had extended mission for the two rovers through
September 2007.[17][18] On February 6, 2007, _Opportunity_ became the first
spacecraft to traverse ten kilometers (6.2 miles) on the surface of Mars.[19]

_Opportunity_ was poised to enter Victoria Crater from its perch on the rim of
Duck Bay on June 28, 2007,[20] but due to extensive dust storms, it was
delayed until the dust had cleared and power returned to safe levels.[21] Two
months later, _Spirit_ and _Opportunity_ resumed driving after hunkering down
during raging dust storms that limited solar power to a level that nearly
caused the permanent failure of both rovers.[22]

On October 1, 2007,[23] both _Spirit_ and _Opportunity_ entered their fifth
mission extension that extended operations into 2009,[24] allowing the rovers
to have spent five years exploring the Martian surface, pending their
continued survival.

On August 26, 2008, _Opportunity_ began its three-day climb out of Victoria
crater amidst concerns that power spikes, similar to those seen on _Spirit_
before the failure of its right-front wheel, might prevent it from ever being
able to leave the crater if a wheel failed. Project scientist Bruce Banerdt
also said, "We've done everything we entered Victoria Crater to do and more."
_Opportunity_ will return to the plains in order to characterize Meridiani
Planum's vast diversity of rocks—some of which may have been blasted out of
craters such as Victoria. The rover had been exploring Victoria Crater since
September 11, 2007.[25][26] As of January 2009, the two rovers had
collectively sent back 250,000 images and traveled over 21 kilometers (13
mi).[27]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Driving_Distances_on_Mars_and_the_Moon.png/250px-
Driving_Distances_on_Mars_and_the_Moon.png)](/wiki/File:Driving_Distances_on_Mars_and_the_Moon.png)

[](/wiki/File:Driving_Distances_on_Mars_and_the_Moon.png "Enlarge")

Comparison of distances driven by various wheeled vehicles on the surface of
Earth's [moon](/wiki/Moon "Moon") and [Mars](/wiki/Mars "Mars") (July 28,
2014).

After driving about 3.2 kilometers (2.0 mi) since it left Victoria crater,
_Opportunity_ first saw the rim of [Endeavour
crater](/wiki/Endeavour_\(crater\) "Endeavour \(crater\)") on March 7,
2009.[28][29] It passed the 16 km (9.9 mi) mark along the way on sol 1897.[30]
Meanwhile, at Gusev crater, _Spirit_ was dug in deep into the Martian sand,
much as _Opportunity_ was at [Purgatory
Dune](/wiki/Opportunity_rover#Trouble_with_sand_trap "Opportunity rover") in
2005.[31]

On January 3 and January 24, 2010, _Spirit_ and _Opportunity_ marked six years
on Mars, respectively.[32] On January 26, NASA announced that _Spirit_ will be
used as a stationary research platform after several months of unsuccessful
attempts to free the rover from soft sand.[33]

NASA announced on March 24, 2010, that _Opportunity_ , which has an estimated
remaining drive distance of 12 km to Endeavour Crater, has traveled over 20 km
since the start of its mission.[34] Each rover was designed with a mission
driving distance goal of just 600 meters.[34] One week later, they announced
that _Spirit_ may have gone into hibernation for the Martian winter and might
not wake up again for months.[35]

On September 8, 2010, it was announced that _Opportunity_ had reached the
halfway point of the 19-kilometer journey between Victoria crater and
Endeavour crater.[36]

On May 22, 2011, NASA announced that it will cease attempts to contact
_Spirit_ , which has been stuck in a sand trap for two years. The last
successful communication with the rover was on March 22, 2010. The final
transmission to the rover was on May 25, 2011.[37]

In April 2013, a photo sent back by one of the rovers became widely circulated
on social networking and news sites such as [Reddit](/wiki/Reddit "Reddit")
that appeared to depict a [human penis](/wiki/Human_penis "Human penis")
carved into the Martian dirt.[38][39]

On May 16, 2013, NASA announced that _Opportunity_ had driven further than any
other NASA vehicle on a world other than Earth.[40] After _Opportunity 's_
total odometry went over 35.744 km (22.210 mi), the rover surpassed the total
distance driven by the [Apollo 17](/wiki/Apollo_17 "Apollo 17") [Lunar Roving
Vehicle](/wiki/Lunar_Roving_Vehicle "Lunar Roving Vehicle").[40]

On July 28, 2014, NASA announced that _Opportunity_ had driven further than
any other vehicle on a world other than Earth.[40][41][42] _Opportunity_
covered over 40 km (25 mi), surpassing the total distance of 39 km (24 mi)
driven by the [Lunokhod 2](/wiki/Lunokhod_2 "Lunokhod 2") [lunar
rover](/wiki/Lunar_rover "Lunar rover"), the previous record-holder.[40][41]

On March 23, 2015, NASA announced that _Opportunity_ had driven the full 42.2
km (26.2 mi) distance of a marathon, with a finish time of roughly 11 years, 2
months.[43]

## Spacecraft
design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Spacecraft design")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Fusee_Delta_II_lancement_rover_Mars.jpg/220px-
Fusee_Delta_II_lancement_rover_Mars.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fusee_Delta_II_lancement_rover_Mars.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Fusee_Delta_II_lancement_rover_Mars.jpg "Enlarge")

MER launch configuration, break apart illustration

The Mars Exploration Rover was designed to be stowed in the nose of a [Delta
II rocket](/wiki/Delta_II_rocket "Delta II rocket"). Each spacecraft consists
of several components:

  * Rover: 185 kg (408 lb)
  * Lander: 348 kg (767 lb)
  * Backshell / Parachute: 209 kg (461 lb)
  * Heat Shield: 78 kg (172 lb)
  * Cruise Stage: 193 kg (425 lb)
  * Propellant: 50 kg (110 lb)
  * Instruments: 5 kg (11 lb)[44]

Total mass is 1,063 kg (2,344 lb).

### Cruise
stage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Cruise stage")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Opportunity_Cruise_Stage.jpg/220px-
Opportunity_Cruise_Stage.jpg)](/wiki/File:Opportunity_Cruise_Stage.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Opportunity_Cruise_Stage.jpg "Enlarge")

Cruise stage of _Opportunity_ rover

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/MER_cruise_stage_diagram.jpg/220px-
MER_cruise_stage_diagram.jpg)](/wiki/File:MER_cruise_stage_diagram.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MER_cruise_stage_diagram.jpg "Enlarge")

MER cruise stage diagram

The cruise stage is the component of the spacecraft that is used for travel
from Earth to Mars. It is very similar to the Mars Pathfinder in design and is
approximately 2.65 [meters](/wiki/Metre "Metre") (8.7 ft) in
[diameter](/wiki/Diameter "Diameter") and 1.6 m (5.2 ft) tall, including the
entry vehicle (see below).

The primary structure is aluminium with an outer ring of ribs covered by the
[solar panels](/wiki/Photovoltaic_module "Photovoltaic module"), which are
about 2.65 m (8.7 ft) in diameter. Divided into five sections, the solar
arrays can provide up to 600 [watts](/wiki/Watt "Watt") of power near Earth
and 300 W at Mars.

Heaters and [multi-layer insulation](/wiki/Multi-layer_insulation "Multi-layer
insulation") keep the electronics "warm". A [freon](/wiki/Freon "Freon")
system removes heat from the flight computer and communications hardware
inside the rover so they do not overheat. Cruise avionics systems allow the
flight computer to interface with other electronics, such as the sun sensors,
star scanner and heaters.

####
Navigation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Navigation")]

The star scanner (without a backup system) and [sun sensor](/wiki/Sun_sensor
"Sun sensor") allowed the spacecraft to know its orientation in space by
analyzing the position of the Sun and other stars in relation to itself.
Sometimes the craft could be slightly off course; this was expected, given the
500-million-kilometer (320 million mile) journey. Thus navigators planned up
to six trajectory correction maneuvers, along with health checks.

To ensure the spacecraft arrived at Mars in the right place for its landing,
two light-weight, aluminium-lined tanks carried about 31 kg (about 68 lb) of
[hydrazine](/wiki/Hydrazine "Hydrazine") [propellant](/wiki/Propellant
"Propellant"). Along with cruise guidance and control systems, the propellant
allowed navigators to keep the spacecraft on course. Burns and pulse firings
of the propellant allowed three types of maneuvers:

  * An axial burn uses pairs of thrusters to change spacecraft velocity;
  * A lateral burn uses two "thruster clusters" (four thrusters per cluster) to move the spacecraft "sideways" through seconds-long pulses;
  * Pulse mode firing uses coupled thruster pairs for spacecraft [precession](/wiki/Precession "Precession") maneuvers (turns).

####
Communication[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Communication")]

The spacecraft used a high-frequency [X band](/wiki/X_band "X band")
[radio](/wiki/Radio "Radio") [wavelength](/wiki/Wavelength "Wavelength") to
communicate, which allowed for less power and smaller
[antennas](/wiki/Antenna_\(electronics\) "Antenna \(electronics\)") than many
older craft, which used [S band](/wiki/S_band "S band").

Navigators sent commands through two antennas on the cruise stage: a cruise
[low-gain antenna](/wiki/Low-gain_antenna "Low-gain antenna") mounted inside
the inner ring, and a cruise medium-gain antenna in the outer ring. The low-
gain antenna was used close to Earth. It is omni-directional, so the
transmission power that reached Earth fell faster with increasing distance. As
the craft moved closer to Mars, the Sun and Earth moved closer in the sky as
viewed from the craft, so less energy reached Earth. The spacecraft then
switched to the medium-gain antenna, which directed the same amount of
transmission power into a tighter beam toward Earth.

During flight, the spacecraft was [spin-stabilized](/wiki/Gyroscope
"Gyroscope") with a spin rate of two [revolutions per
minute](/wiki/Revolutions_per_minute "Revolutions per minute") (rpm). Periodic
updates kept antennas pointed toward Earth and solar panels toward the Sun.

###
Aeroshell[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Aeroshell")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Mars_Rover_Aeroshell.jpg/250px-
Mars_Rover_Aeroshell.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mars_Rover_Aeroshell.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mars_Rover_Aeroshell.jpg "Enlarge")

Overview of the Mars Exploration Rover aeroshell

The aeroshell maintained a protective covering for the lander during the
seven-month voyage to Mars. Together with the lander and the rover, it
constituted the "entry vehicle". Its main purpose was to protect the lander
and the rover inside it from the intense heat of entry into the thin Martian
atmosphere. It was based on the Mars Pathfinder and Mars Viking designs.

####
Parts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Parts")]

The aeroshell was made of two main parts: a [heat shield](/wiki/Heat_shield
"Heat shield") and a backshell. The heat shield was flat and brownish, and
protected the lander and rover during entry into the Martian atmosphere and
acted as the first [aerobrake](/wiki/Aerobrake "Aerobrake") for the
spacecraft. The backshell was large, cone-shaped and painted white. It carried
the [parachute](/wiki/Parachute "Parachute") and several components used in
later stages of entry, descent, and landing, including:

  * A parachute (stowed at the bottom of the backshell);
  * The backshell electronics and batteries that fire off pyrotechnic devices like separation nuts, rockets and the parachute mortar;
  * A Litton LN-200 Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU), which monitors and reports the orientation of the backshell as it swings under the parachute;
  * Three large [solid rocket](/wiki/Solid_rocket "Solid rocket") motors called RAD rockets (Rocket Assisted Descent), each providing about a ton of force (10 [kilonewtons](/wiki/Kilonewton "Kilonewton")) for about 60 seconds;
  * Three small solid rockets called TIRS (mounted so that they aim horizontally out the sides of the backshell) that provide a small horizontal kick to the backshell to help orient the backshell more vertically during the main RAD rocket burn.

####
Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Composition")]

Built by the [Lockheed Martin](/wiki/Lockheed_Martin "Lockheed Martin")
Astronautics Co. in Denver, Colorado, the aeroshell is made of an aluminium
honeycomb structure sandwiched between [graphite-epoxy](/wiki/Graphite-epoxy
"Graphite-epoxy") face sheets. The outside of the aeroshell is covered with a
layer of [phenolic](/wiki/Phenol "Phenol") honeycomb. This honeycomb is filled
with an [ablative](/wiki/Ablation "Ablation") material (also called an
"ablator"), that dissipates heat generated by atmospheric friction.

The ablator itself is a unique blend of [cork](/wiki/Cork_\(material\) "Cork
\(material\)") wood, [binder](/wiki/Binder_\(material\) "Binder \(material\)")
and many tiny [silica](/wiki/Silica "Silica") glass spheres. It was invented
for the heat shields flown on the Viking Mars lander missions. A similar
technology was used in the first US [manned space
missions](/wiki/Manned_space_mission "Manned space mission")
[Mercury](/wiki/Mercury_program "Mercury program"),
[Gemini](/wiki/Gemini_program "Gemini program") and
[Apollo](/wiki/Apollo_program "Apollo program"). It was specially formulated
to react chemically with the Martian atmosphere during
[entry](/wiki/Atmospheric_entry "Atmospheric entry") and carry heat away,
leaving a hot wake of gas behind the vehicle. The vehicle slowed from 19,000
to 1,600 km/h (5,300 to 440 m/s) in about a minute, producing about 60 m/s2 (6
_[g](/wiki/G-force "G-force")_) of [acceleration](/wiki/Acceleration
"Acceleration") on the lander and rover.

The backshell and heat shield are made of the same materials, but the heat
shield has a thicker, 13 mm (1⁄2 in), layer of the ablator. Instead of being
painted, the backshell was covered with a very thin aluminized [PET
film](/wiki/PET_film_\(biaxially_oriented\) "PET film \(biaxially oriented\)")
blanket to protect it from the cold of deep space. The blanket vaporized
during entry into the Martian atmosphere.

###
Parachute[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Parachute")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Parachute1.jpg/220px-
Parachute1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Parachute1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Parachute1.jpg "Enlarge")

Mars Exploration Rover's parachute test

The parachute helped slow the spacecraft during entry, descent, and landing.
It is located in the backshell.[45]

####
Design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Design")]

The 2003 parachute design was part of a long-term Mars parachute technology
development effort and is based on the designs and experience of the Viking
and Pathfinder missions. The parachute for this mission is 40% larger than
Pathfinder's because the largest load for the Mars Exploration Rover is 80 to
85 [kilonewtons](/wiki/Newton_\(units\) "Newton \(units\)") (kN) or 80 to 85
kN (18,000 to 19,000 lbf) when the parachute fully inflates. By comparison,
Pathfinder's inflation loads were approximately 35 kN (about 8,000 lbf). The
parachute was designed and constructed in [South Windsor,
Connecticut](/wiki/South_Windsor,_Connecticut "South Windsor, Connecticut") by
[Pioneer Aerospace](/wiki/Pioneer_Aerospace "Pioneer Aerospace"), the company
that also designed the parachute for the
_[Stardust](/wiki/Stardust_\(spacecraft\) "Stardust \(spacecraft\)")_
mission.[45]

####
Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Composition")]

The parachute is made of two durable, lightweight fabrics:
[polyester](/wiki/Polyester "Polyester") and [nylon](/wiki/Nylon "Nylon"). A
triple bridle made of [Kevlar](/wiki/Kevlar "Kevlar") connects the parachute
to the backshell.

The amount of space available on the spacecraft for the parachute is so small
that the parachute had to be pressure-packed. Before launch, a team tightly
folded the 48 suspension lines, three bridle lines, and the parachute. The
parachute team loaded the parachute in a special structure that then applied a
heavy weight to the parachute package several times. Before placing the
parachute into the backshell, the parachute was heat set to
[sterilize](/wiki/Sterilization_\(microbiology\) "Sterilization
\(microbiology\)") it.[45]

#### Connected
systems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Connected systems")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Rocket_assisted_descent.jpg/220px-
Rocket_assisted_descent.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rocket_assisted_descent.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rocket_assisted_descent.jpg "Enlarge")

Descent is halted by [retrorockets](/wiki/Retrorocket "Retrorocket") and
lander is dropped 10 m (33 ft) to the surface in this computer generated
impression.

**Zylon Bridles** : After the parachute was deployed at an altitude of about
10 km (6.2 mi) above the surface, the heatshield was released using 6
separation nuts and push-off springs. The lander then separated from the
backshell and "rappelled" down a metal tape on a [centrifugal braking
system](/w/index.php?title=Centrifugal_brake&action=edit&redlink=1
"Centrifugal brake \(page does not exist\)") built into one of the lander
petals. The slow descent down the metal tape placed the lander in position at
the end of another bridle (tether), made of a nearly 20 m (66 ft) long braided
[Zylon](/wiki/Zylon "Zylon").[45]

Zylon is an advanced fiber material, similar to Kevlar, that is sewn in a
webbing pattern (like shoelace material) to make it stronger. The Zylon bridle
provides space for airbag deployment, distance from the solid rocket motor
exhaust stream, and increased stability. The bridle incorporates an electrical
harness that allows the firing of the solid rockets from the backshell as well
as provides data from the backshell inertial measurement unit (which measures
rate and tilt of the spacecraft) to the flight computer in the rover.[45]

**Rocket assisted descent (RAD)** motors: Because the atmospheric density of
Mars is less than 1% of Earth's, the parachute alone could not slow down the
Mars Exploration Rover enough to ensure a safe, low landing speed. The
spacecraft descent was assisted by rockets that brought the spacecraft to a
dead stop 10–15 m (33–49 ft) above the Martian surface.[45]

**Radar altimeter unit** : A [radar](/wiki/Radar "Radar")
[altimeter](/wiki/Altimeter "Altimeter") unit was used to determine the
distance to the Martian surface. The radar's antenna is mounted at one of the
lower corners of the lander tetrahedron. When the radar measurement showed the
lander was the correct distance above the surface, the Zylon bridle was cut,
releasing the lander from the parachute and backshell so that it was free and
clear for landing. The radar data also enabled the timing sequence on airbag
inflation and backshell RAD rocket firing.[45]

###
Airbags[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Airbags")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Airbags.jpg/220px-
Airbags.jpg)](/wiki/File:Airbags.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Airbags.jpg "Enlarge")

Artist's concept of inflated airbags

[Airbags](/wiki/Airbag "Airbag") used in the Mars Exploration Rover mission
are the same type that Mars Pathfinder used in 1997. They had to be strong
enough to cushion the spacecraft if it landed on rocks or rough terrain and
allow it to bounce across Mars' surface at highway speeds (about 100 km/h)
after landing. The airbags had to be inflated seconds before touchdown and
deflated once safely on the ground.

The airbags were made of [Vectran](/wiki/Vectran "Vectran"), like those on
Pathfinder. Vectran has almost twice the strength of other synthetic
materials, such as Kevlar, and performs better in cold temperatures. Six 100
[denier](/wiki/Denier_\(measure\) "Denier \(measure\)") (10 mg/m) layers of
Vectran protected one or two inner bladders of Vectran in 200 denier (20
mg/m). Using 100 denier (10 mg/m) leaves more fabric in the outer layers where
it is needed, because there are more threads in the weave.

Each rover used four airbags with six lobes each, all of which were connected.
Connection was important, since it helped abate some of the landing forces by
keeping the bag system flexible and responsive to ground pressure. The airbags
were not attached directly to the rover, but were held to it by ropes
crisscrossing the bag structure. The ropes gave the bags shape, making
inflation easier. While in flight, the bags were stowed along with three gas
generators that are used for inflation.

###
Lander[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Lander")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Opportunity_Lander_Petals_PIA04848.jpg/220px-
Opportunity_Lander_Petals_PIA04848.jpg)](/wiki/File:Opportunity_Lander_Petals_PIA04848.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Opportunity_Lander_Petals_PIA04848.jpg "Enlarge")

MER lander petals opening (Courtesy NASA/JPL-Caltech)

The spacecraft lander is a protective shell that houses the rover, and
together with the airbags, protects it from the forces of impact.

The lander is a [tetrahedron](/wiki/Tetrahedron "Tetrahedron") shape, whose
sides open like petals. It is strong and light, and made of beams and sheets.
The beams consist of layers of [graphite](/wiki/Graphite "Graphite") fiber
woven into a fabric that is lighter than aluminium and more rigid than steel.
Titanium fittings are glued and fitted onto the beams to allow it to be bolted
together. The rover was held inside the lander by [bolts](/wiki/Screw "Screw")
and special nuts that were released after landing with small explosives.

####
Uprighting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Uprighting")]

After the lander stopped bouncing and rolling on the ground, it came to rest
on the base of the tetrahedron or one of its sides. The sides then opened to
make the base horizontal and the rover upright. The sides are connected to the
base by hinges, each of which has a motor strong enough to lift the lander.
The rover plus lander has a [mass](/wiki/Mass "Mass") of about 533 kilograms
(1,175 [pounds](/wiki/Pound_\(mass\) "Pound \(mass\)")). The rover alone has a
mass of about 185 kg (408 lb). The gravity on Mars is about 38% of Earth's, so
the motor does not need to be as powerful as it would on Earth.

The rover contains [accelerometers](/wiki/Accelerometer "Accelerometer") to
detect which way is down (toward the surface of Mars) by measuring the pull of
gravity. The rover computer then commanded the correct lander petal to open to
place the rover upright. Once the base petal was down and the rover was
upright, the other two petals were opened.

The petals initially opened to an equally flat position, so all sides of the
lander were straight and level. The petal motors are strong enough so that if
two of the petals come to rest on rocks, the base with the rover would be held
in place like a bridge above the ground. The base will hold at a level even
with the height of the petals resting on rocks, making a straight flat surface
throughout the length of the open, flattened lander. The flight team on Earth
could then send commands to the rover to adjust the petals and create a safe
path for the rover to drive off the lander and onto the Martian surface
without dropping off a steep rock.

#### Moving the payload onto
Mars[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Moving the payload onto Mars")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/MER_Spirit_Lander_Pan_Sol16-A18R1_br2.jpg/220px-
MER_Spirit_Lander_Pan_Sol16-A18R1_br2.jpg)](/wiki/File:MER_Spirit_Lander_Pan_Sol16-A18R1_br2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MER_Spirit_Lander_Pan_Sol16-A18R1_br2.jpg "Enlarge")

_Spirit '_s lander on Mars

The moving of the rover off the lander is called the egress phase of the
mission. The rover must avoid having its wheels caught in the airbag material
or falling off a sharp incline. To help this, a retraction system on the
petals slowly drags the airbags toward the lander before the petals open.
Small ramps on the petals fan out to fill spaces between the petals. They
cover uneven terrain, rock obstacles, and airbag material, and form a circular
area from which the rover can drive off in more directions. They also lower
the step that the rover must climb down. They are nicknamed "batwings", and
are made of Vectran cloth.

About three hours were allotted to retract the airbags and deploy the lander
petals.

## Rover
design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Rover design")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/MER_vs._Sojourner_PIA04827.jpg/220px-
MER_vs._Sojourner_PIA04827.jpg)](/wiki/File:MER_vs._Sojourner_PIA04827.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MER_vs._Sojourner_PIA04827.jpg "Enlarge")

Mars Exploration Rover (rear) vs. [_Sojourner_](/wiki/Mars_Pathfinder "Mars
Pathfinder") rover (Courtesy NASA/JPL-Caltech)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Mars_Exploration_Rover.stl/220px-
Mars_Exploration_Rover.stl.png)3D](/wiki/File:Mars_Exploration_Rover.stl)

[](/wiki/File:Mars_Exploration_Rover.stl "Enlarge")

Interactive 3D model of the MER

The rovers are six-wheeled, solar-powered robots that stand 1.5 m (4.9 ft)
high, 2.3 m (7.5 ft) wide and 1.6 m (5.2 ft) long. They weigh 180 kg (400 lb),
35 kg (77 lb) of which is the wheel and suspension system.[46]

### Drive
system[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Drive system")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/NASA_MER_FLEXURE_WHEEL.jpg/220px-
NASA_MER_FLEXURE_WHEEL.jpg)](/wiki/File:NASA_MER_FLEXURE_WHEEL.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NASA_MER_FLEXURE_WHEEL.jpg "Enlarge")

Drive wheel from the Mars Exploration Rovers, with integral suspension
[flexures](/wiki/Flexure "Flexure").

Each rover has six wheels mounted on a [rocker-bogie](/wiki/Rocker-bogie
"Rocker-bogie") suspension system that ensures wheels remain on the ground
while driving over rough terrain. The design reduces the range of motion of
the rover body by half, and allows the rover to go over obstacles or through
holes that are more than a wheel diameter (250 millimeters (9.8 in)) in size.
The rover wheels are designed with integral compliant [flexures](/wiki/Flexure
"Flexure") which provide shock absorption during movement.[47] Additionally,
the wheels have cleats which provide grip for climbing in soft sand and
scrambling over rocks.

Each wheel has its own drive motor. The two front and two rear wheels each
have individual steering motors. This allows the vehicle to turn in place, a
full revolution, and to swerve and curve, making arching turns. The rover is
designed to withstand a tilt of 45 degrees in any direction without
overturning. However, the rover is programmed through its "fault protection
limits" in its hazard avoidance software to avoid exceeding tilts of 30
degrees.

Each rover can spin one of its front wheels in place to grind deep into the
terrain. It is to remain motionless while the digging wheel is spinning. The
rovers have a top speed on flat hard ground of 50 mm/s (2 in/s). The average
speed is 10 mm/s, because its hazard avoidance software causes it to stop
every 10 seconds for 20 seconds to observe and understand the terrain into
which it has driven.

### Power and electronic
systems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Power and electronic systems")]

See also: [Comparison of embedded computer systems on board the Mars
rovers](/wiki/Comparison_of_embedded_computer_systems_on_board_the_Mars_rovers
"Comparison of embedded computer systems on board the Mars rovers")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Mars_Spirit_rover%27s_solar_panels_covered_with_Dust_-
_October_2007.jpg/220px-Mars_Spirit_rover%27s_solar_panels_covered_with_Dust_-
_October_2007.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mars_Spirit_rover%27s_solar_panels_covered_with_Dust_-
_October_2007.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mars_Spirit_rover%27s_solar_panels_covered_with_Dust_-
_October_2007.jpg "Enlarge")

Circular projection showing MER-A _Spirit '_s solar panels covered in dust in
October 2007 on Mars. Unexpected [cleaning events](/wiki/Cleaning_event
"Cleaning event") have periodically increased power.

When fully illuminated, the rover
[triplejunction](/wiki/Multijunction_photovoltaic_cell "Multijunction
photovoltaic cell")[48] solar arrays generate about 140 watts for up to four
hours per Martian day ([sol](/wiki/Timekeeping_on_Mars#Sols "Timekeeping on
Mars")). The rover needs about 100 watts to drive. Its power system includes
two rechargeable [lithium ion](/wiki/Lithium_ion "Lithium ion") batteries
weighing 7.15 kg (15.8 lb) each, that provide energy when the sun is not
shining, especially at night. Over time, the batteries will degrade and will
not be able to recharge to full capacity.

For comparison, the [Mars Science Laboratory](/wiki/Mars_Science_Laboratory
"Mars Science Laboratory")'s power system is composed of a [Multi-Mission
Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator](/wiki/Multi-
Mission_Radioisotope_Thermoelectric_Generator "Multi-Mission Radioisotope
Thermoelectric Generator") (MMRTG) produced by Boeing.[49] The MMRTG is
designed to provide 125W of electrical power at the start of the mission,
falling to 100W after 14 years of service.[50] It is used to power the MSL's
many systems and instruments. Solar panels were also considered for the MSL,
but RTGs provide constant power, regardless of the time of day, and thus the
versatility to work in dark environments and high latitudes where solar energy
is not readily available. The MSL generates 2.5 [kilowatt
hours](/wiki/Kilowatt_hour "Kilowatt hour") per day, compared to the Mars
Exploration Rovers, which can generate about 0.6 kilowatt hours per day.[51]

It was thought that by the end of the 90-sol mission, the capability of the
solar arrays to generate power would likely be reduced to about 50 watts. This
was due to anticipated dust coverage on the solar arrays, and the change in
season. Over three Earth years later, however, the rovers' power supplies
hovered between 300 [watt-hours](/wiki/Watt-hour "Watt-hour") and 900 watt-
hours per day, depending on dust coverage. Cleaning events (dust removal by
wind) have occurred more often than NASA expected, keeping the arrays
relatively free of dust and extending the life of the mission. During a 2007
global dust storm on Mars, both rovers experienced some of the lowest power of
the mission; _Opportunity_ dipped to 128 watt-hours. In November 2008, Spirit
had overtaken this low-energy record with a production of 89 watt-hours, due
to dust storms in the region of Gusev crater.[52]

The rovers run a [VxWorks](/wiki/VxWorks "VxWorks") [embedded operating
system](/wiki/Embedded_operating_system "Embedded operating system") on a
[radiation-hardened](/wiki/Radiation_hardened "Radiation hardened") 20
[MHz](/wiki/Megahertz "Megahertz") [RAD6000](/wiki/RAD6000 "RAD6000")
[CPU](/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central processing unit") with 128
[MB](/wiki/Megabyte "Megabyte") of [DRAM](/wiki/DRAM "DRAM") with error
detection and correction and 3 MB of [EEPROM](/wiki/EEPROM "EEPROM"). Each
rover also has 256 MB of [flash memory](/wiki/Flash_memory "Flash memory"). To
survive during the various mission phases, the rover's vital instruments must
stay within a temperature of −40 °C to +40 °C (−40 °F to 104 °F). At night,
the rovers are heated by eight [radioisotope heater
units](/wiki/Radioisotope_heater_units "Radioisotope heater units") (RHU),
which each continuously generate 1 [W](/wiki/Watt "Watt") of thermal energy
from the decay of [radioisotopes](/wiki/Radioisotope "Radioisotope"), along
with electrical heaters that operate only when necessary. A sputtered gold
film and a layer of [silica](/wiki/Silica "Silica") [aerogel](/wiki/Aerogel
"Aerogel") are used for insulation.

###
Communication[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Communication")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/MER_Pancam.JPG/220px-
MER_Pancam.JPG)](/wiki/File:MER_Pancam.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:MER_Pancam.JPG "Enlarge")

Pancam Mast Assembly (PMA)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/MER_Rock_Abrasion_Tool.JPG/220px-
MER_Rock_Abrasion_Tool.JPG)](/wiki/File:MER_Rock_Abrasion_Tool.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:MER_Rock_Abrasion_Tool.JPG "Enlarge")

Rock Abrasion Tool (RAT)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/MER_APXS_PIA05113.jpg/220px-
MER_APXS_PIA05113.jpg)](/wiki/File:MER_APXS_PIA05113.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MER_APXS_PIA05113.jpg "Enlarge")

[Alpha particle X-ray spectrometer](/wiki/Alpha_particle_X-ray_spectrometer
"Alpha particle X-ray spectrometer") (APXS) (Courtesy NASA/JPL-Caltech)

The rover has an [X band](/wiki/X_band "X band") [low-gain](/wiki/Low-
gain_antenna "Low-gain antenna") and an X band [high-gain antenna](/wiki/High-
gain_antenna "High-gain antenna") for communications to and from the Earth, as
well as an [ultra high frequency](/wiki/Ultra_high_frequency "Ultra high
frequency") monopole antenna for relay communications. The low-gain antenna is
[omnidirectional](/wiki/Omnidirectional_antenna "Omnidirectional antenna"),
and transmits data at a low rate to [Deep Space
Network](/wiki/Deep_Space_Network "Deep Space Network") (DSN) antennas on
Earth. The high-gain antenna is directional and steerable, and can transmit
data to Earth at a higher rate. The rovers use the UHF monopole and its CE505
radio to communicate with spacecraft orbiting Mars, the [Mars
Odyssey](/wiki/Mars_Odyssey "Mars Odyssey") and (before its failure) the [Mars
Global Surveyor](/wiki/Mars_Global_Surveyor "Mars Global Surveyor") (already
more than 7.6 [terabits](/wiki/Terabit "Terabit") of data were transferred
using its Mars Relay antenna and [Mars Orbiter
Camera](/wiki/Mars_Orbiter_Camera "Mars Orbiter Camera")'s memory buffer of 12
MB).[53] Since [MRO](/wiki/Mars_Reconnaissance_Orbiter "Mars Reconnaissance
Orbiter") went into orbit around Mars, the landers have also used it as a
relay asset. Most of the lander data is relayed to Earth through Odyssey and
MRO. The orbiters can receive rover signals at a much higher data rate than
the Deep Space Network can, due to the much shorter distances from rover to
orbiter. The orbiters then quickly relay the rover data to the Earth using
their large and [high-powered](/wiki/Signal_strength "Signal strength")
antennas.

Each rover has nine cameras, which produce 1024-pixel by 1024-pixel images at
12 bits per pixel,[54] but most navigation camera images and image thumbnails
are truncated to 8 bits per pixel to conserve memory and transmission time.
All images are then compressed using [ICER](/wiki/ICER "ICER") before being
stored and sent to Earth. Navigation, thumbnail, and many other image types
are compressed to approximately 0.8 to 1.1 bits/pixel. Lower bit rates (less
than 0.5-bit/pixel) are used for certain wavelengths of multi-color panoramic
images.

ICER is based on [wavelets](/wiki/Wavelets "Wavelets"), and was designed
specifically for deep-space applications. It produces progressive compression,
both lossless and lossy, and incorporates an error-containment scheme to limit
the effects of data loss on the deep-space channel. It outperforms the lossy
JPEG image compressor and the lossless Rice compressor used by the [Mars
Pathfinder](/wiki/Mars_Pathfinder "Mars Pathfinder") mission.

### Scientific
instrumentation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Scientific instrumentation")]

The rover has various instruments. Three are mounted on the Pancam Mast
Assembly (PMA):

  * Panoramic Cameras ([Pancam](/wiki/Pancam "Pancam")), two cameras with color filter wheels for determining the texture, color, [mineralogy](/wiki/Mineralogy "Mineralogy"), and structure of the local terrain.
  * Navigation Cameras ([Navcam](/wiki/Navcam "Navcam")), two cameras that have larger fields of view but lower resolution and are monochromatic, for navigation and driving.
  * A periscope assembly for the Miniature Thermal Emission Spectrometer ([Mini-TES](/wiki/Mini-TES "Mini-TES")), which identifies promising rocks and soils for closer examination, and determines the processes that formed them. The Mini-TES was built by [Arizona State University](/wiki/Arizona_State_University "Arizona State University"). The periscope assembly features two beryllium fold mirrors, a shroud that closes to minimize dust contamination in the assembly, and stray-light rejection baffles that are strategically placed within the graphite epoxy tubes.

The cameras are mounted 1.5 meters high on the Pancam Mast Assembly. The PMA
is deployed via the Mast Deployment Drive (MDD). The Azimuth Drive, mounted
directly above the MDD, turns the assembly horizontally a whole revolution
with signals transmitted through a rolling tape configuration. The camera
drive points the cameras in elevation, almost straight up or down. A third
motor points the Mini-TES fold mirrors and protective shroud, up to 30° above
the horizon and 50° below. The PMA's conceptual design was done by Jason
Suchman at JPL, the Cognizant Engineer who later served as Contract Technical
Manager (CTM) once the assembly was built by [Ball Aerospace & Technologies
Corp.](/wiki/Ball_Aerospace_%26_Technologies_Corp. "Ball Aerospace &
Technologies Corp."), [Boulder, Colorado](/wiki/Boulder,_Colorado "Boulder,
Colorado"). Raul Romero served as CTM once subsystem-level testing began.
Satish Krishnan did the conceptual design of the High-Gain Antenna Gimbal
(HGAG), whose detailed design, assembly, and test was also performed by Ball
Aerospace at which point Satish acted as the CTM.

Four monochromatic hazard cameras ([Hazcams](/wiki/Hazcam "Hazcam")) are
mounted on the rover's body, two in front and two behind.

The instrument deployment device (IDD), also called the rover arm, holds the
following:

  * [Mössbauer spectrometer](/wiki/M%C3%B6ssbauer_spectrometer "Mössbauer spectrometer") (MB) [MIMOS II](/wiki/MIMOS_II "MIMOS II"), developed by Dr. Göstar Klingelhöfer at the [Johannes Gutenberg](/wiki/Johannes_Gutenberg "Johannes Gutenberg") University in [Mainz](/wiki/Mainz "Mainz"), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), is used for close-up investigations of the mineralogy of iron-bearing rocks and soils.[55][56]
  * [Alpha particle X-ray spectrometer](/wiki/Alpha_particle_X-ray_spectrometer "Alpha particle X-ray spectrometer") (APXS), developed by the [Max Planck Institute for Chemistry](/wiki/Max_Planck_Institute_for_Chemistry "Max Planck Institute for Chemistry") in [Mainz](/wiki/Mainz "Mainz"), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), is used for close-up analysis of the abundances of elements that make up rocks and soils.[57] Universities involved in developing the APXS include the [University of Guelph](/wiki/University_of_Guelph "University of Guelph"), [University of California](/wiki/University_of_California "University of California"), and [Cornell University](/wiki/Cornell_University "Cornell University")
  * Magnets, for collecting magnetic dust particles,[58] developed by [Jens Martin Knudsen](/wiki/Jens_Martin_Knudsen "Jens Martin Knudsen")'s group at the [Niels Bohr Institute](/wiki/Niels_Bohr_Institute_for_Astronomy,_Physics_and_Geophysics "Niels Bohr Institute for Astronomy, Physics and Geophysics"), [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen"). The particles are analyzed by the Mössbauer Spectrometer and [X-ray](/wiki/X-ray "X-ray") Spectrometer to help determine the ratio of magnetic particles to non-magnetic particles and the composition of magnetic minerals in airborne dust and rocks that have been ground by the Rock Abrasion Tool. There are also magnets on the front of the rover, which are studied extensively by the Mössbauer spectrometer.
  * Microscopic Imager (MI) for obtaining close-up, high-resolution images of rocks and soils. Development was led by Ken Herkenhoff's team at the [USGS](/wiki/USGS "USGS") [Astrogeology Research Program](/wiki/Astrogeology_Research_Program "Astrogeology Research Program").
  * [Rock Abrasion Tool](/wiki/Rock_Abrasion_Tool "Rock Abrasion Tool") (RAT), developed by [Honeybee Robotics](/wiki/Honeybee_Robotics "Honeybee Robotics"), for removing dusty and weathered rock surfaces and exposing fresh material for examination by instruments on board.

The robotic arm is able to place instruments directly up against rock and soil
targets of interest.

## Naming of _Spirit_ and
_Opportunity_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Naming of Spirit and Opportunity")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Sofi_Collis_MER.jpg/220px-
Sofi_Collis_MER.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sofi_Collis_MER.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sofi_Collis_MER.jpg "Enlarge")

Sofi Collis with a model of Mars Exploration Rover

The _Spirit_ and _Opportunity_ rovers were named through a student essay
competition. The winning entry was by Sofi Collis,[59] a third-grade Russian-
American student from Arizona.

> I used to live in an orphanage. It was dark and cold and lonely. At night, I
> looked up at the sparkly sky and felt better. I dreamed I could fly there.
> In America, I can make all my dreams come true. Thank you for the 'Spirit'
> and the 'Opportunity.'  
>  — Sofi Collis, age 9

Prior to this, during the development and building of the rovers, they were
known as MER-1 (_Opportunity_) and MER-2 (_Spirit_). Internally, NASA also
uses the mission designations MER-A (_Spirit_) and MER-B (_Opportunity_) based
on the order of landing on Mars (_Spirit_ first then _Opportunity_).

## Test
rovers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Test rovers")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Rover_testing.jpg/220px-
Rover_testing.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rover_testing.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rover_testing.jpg "Enlarge")

Rover team members simulate _Spirit_ in a Martian sandtrap.

The Jet Propulsion Laboratory maintains a pair of rovers, the _Surface System
Test-Beds_ (SSTB) at its location in Pasadena for testing and modeling of
situations on Mars. One test rover, SSTB1, weighing approximately 180
kilograms (400 lb), is fully instrumented and nearly identical to _Spirit_ and
_Opportunity_. Another test version, _SSTB-Lite_ , is identical in size and
drive characteristics but does not include all instruments. It weighs in at 80
kilograms (180 lb), much closer to the weight of _Spirit_ and _Opportunity_ in
the reduced [gravity of Mars](/wiki/Gravity_of_Mars "Gravity of Mars"). These
rovers were used in 2009 for a simulation of the incident in which _Spirit_
became trapped in soft soil.[60][61][62]

## SAP[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: SAP")]

The NASA team uses a software application called _SAP_ to view images
collected from the rover, and to plan its daily activities. There is a version
available to the public called [Maestro](/wiki/Maestro_\(software\) "Maestro
\(software\)").[63]

findings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Planetary science findings")]

### _Spirit_ Landing Site, Gusev
Crater[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Spirit Landing Site, Gusev Crater")]

####
Plains[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Plains")]

Although the Gusev crater appears from orbital images to be a dry lakebed, the
observations from the surface show the interior plains mostly filled with
debris. The rocks on the plains of Gusev are a type of [basalt](/wiki/Basalt
"Basalt"). They contain the minerals [olivine](/wiki/Olivine "Olivine"),
[pyroxene](/wiki/Pyroxene "Pyroxene"), [plagioclase](/wiki/Plagioclase
"Plagioclase"), and magnetite, and they look like volcanic basalt as they are
fine-grained with irregular holes (geologists would say they have vesicles and
vugs).[64][65] Much of the soil on the plains came from the breakdown of the
local rocks. Fairly high levels of [nickel](/wiki/Nickel "Nickel") were found
in some soils; probably from [meteorites](/wiki/Meteorites "Meteorites").[66]
Analysis shows that the rocks have been slightly altered by tiny amounts of
water. Outside coatings and cracks inside the rocks suggest water deposited
minerals, maybe [bromine](/wiki/Bromine "Bromine") compounds. All the rocks
contain a fine coating of dust and one or more harder rinds of material. One
type can be brushed off, while another needed to be ground off by the [Rock
Abrasion Tool](/wiki/Rock_Abrasion_Tool "Rock Abrasion Tool") (RAT).[67]

There are a variety of rocks in the [Columbia
Hills](/wiki/Columbia_Hills_\(Mars\) "Columbia Hills \(Mars\)"), some of which
have been altered by water, but not by very much water.

Adirondack
[![Adirondacksquare.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Adirondacksquare.jpg/260px-
Adirondacksquare.jpg)](/wiki/File:Adirondacksquare.jpg)  
---  
Coordinates|  [14°36′S 175°30′E﻿ / ﻿14.6°S 175.5°E﻿ / -14.6;
175.5](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mars_Exploration_Rover&params=14.6_S_175.5_E_globe:mars_type:landmark)[Coordinates](/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system
"Geographic coordinate system"): [14°36′S 175°30′E﻿ / ﻿14.6°S 175.5°E﻿ /
-14.6;
175.5](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mars_Exploration_Rover&params=14.6_S_175.5_E_globe:mars_type:landmark)  
  
These rocks can be classified in different ways. The amounts and types of
minerals make the rocks primitive basalts—also called picritic basalts. The
rocks are similar to ancient terrestrial rocks called basaltic
[komatiites](/wiki/Komatiites "Komatiites"). Rocks of the plains also resemble
the basaltic [shergottites](/wiki/Shergottite "Shergottite"), meteorites which
came from Mars. One classification system compares the amount of alkali
elements to the amount of silica on a graph; in this system, Gusev plains
rocks lie near the junction of basalt, [picrobasalt](/wiki/Picrobasalt
"Picrobasalt"), and tephite. The Irvine-Barager classification calls them
basalts.[64] Plain’s rocks have been very slightly altered, probably by thin
films of water because they are softer and contain veins of light colored
material that may be bromine compounds, as well as coatings or rinds. It is
thought that small amounts of water may have gotten into cracks inducing
mineralization processes).[65][64] Coatings on the rocks may have occurred
when rocks were buried and interacted with thin films of water and dust. One
sign that they were altered was that it was easier to grind these rocks
compared to the same types of rocks found on Earth.

The first rock that _Spirit_ studied was Adirondack. It turned out to be
typical of the other rocks on the plains.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Spirit%27s_First_Color_Photograph_Mars.jpg/191px-Spirit%27s_First_Color_Photograph_Mars.jpg)](/wiki/File:Spirit%27s_First_Color_Photograph_Mars.jpg)

First color picture from Gusev crater. Rocks were found to be basalt.
Everything was covered with a fine dust that _Spirit_ determined was magnetic
because of the mineral magnetite.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Rockgusev.jpg/200px-Rockgusev.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rockgusev.jpg)

Cross-sectional drawing of a typical rock from the plains of Gusev crater.
Most rocks contain a coating of dust and one or more harder coatings. Veins of
water-deposited veins are visible, along with crystals of olivine. Veins may
contain bromine salts.

####
Dust[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Dust")]

The dust in Gusev Crater is the same as dust all around the planet. All the
dust was found to be magnetic. Moreover, _Spirit_ found the
[magnetism](/wiki/Magnetism "Magnetism") was caused by the mineral
[magnetite](/wiki/Magnetite "Magnetite"), especially magnetite that contained
the element [titanium](/wiki/Titanium "Titanium"). One magnet was able to
completely divert all dust hence all Martian dust is thought to be
magnetic.[68] The spectra of the dust was similar to spectra of bright, low
thermal inertia regions like [Tharsis](/wiki/Tharsis "Tharsis") and Arabia
that have been detected by orbiting satellites. A thin layer of dust, maybe
less than one millimeter thick covers all surfaces. Something in it contains a
small amount of chemically bound water.[69][70]

#### Columbia
Hills[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Columbia Hills")]

As the rover climbed above the plains onto the Columbia Hills, the mineralogy
that was seen changed.[71][72] Scientists found a variety of rock types in the
Columbia Hills, and they placed them into six different categories. The six
are: Clovis, Wishbone, Peace, Watchtower, Backstay, and Independence. They are
named after a prominent rock in each group. Their chemical compositions, as
measured by APXS, are significantly different from each other.[73] Most
importantly, all of the rocks in Columbia Hills show various degrees of
alteration due to aqueous fluids.[74] They are enriched in the elements
phosphorus, sulfur, chlorine, and bromine—all of which can be carried around
in water solutions. The Columbia Hills’ rocks contain basaltic glass, along
with varying amounts of olivine and [sulfates](/wiki/Sulfate
"Sulfate").[75][76] The olivine abundance varies inversely with the amount of
sulfates. This is exactly what is expected because water destroys olivine but
helps to produce sulfates.

The Clovis group is especially interesting because the [Mössbauer
spectrometer](/wiki/M%C3%B6ssbauer_spectrometer "Mössbauer spectrometer") (MB)
detected [goethite](/wiki/Goethite "Goethite") in it.[77] Goethite forms only
in the presence of water, so its discovery is the first direct evidence of
past water in the Columbia Hills's rocks. In addition, the MB spectra of rocks
and outcrops displayed a strong decline in olivine presence,[75] although the
rocks probably once contained much olivine.[78] Olivine is a marker for the
lack of water because it easily decomposes in the presence of water. Sulfate
was found, and it needs water to form. Wishstone contained a great deal of
plagioclase, some olivine, and [anhydrate](/wiki/Anhydrate "Anhydrate") (a
sulfate). Peace rocks showed [sulfur](/wiki/Sulfur "Sulfur") and strong
evidence for bound water, so hydrated sulfates are suspected. Watchtower class
rocks lack olivine consequently they may have been altered by water. The
Independence class showed some signs of clay (perhaps montmorillonite a member
of the smectite group). Clays require fairly long term exposure to water to
form. One type of soil, called Paso Robles, from the Columbia Hills, may be an
evaporate deposit because it contains large amounts of sulfur,
[phosphorus](/wiki/Phosphorus "Phosphorus"), [calcium](/wiki/Calcium
"Calcium"), and iron.[79] Also, MB found that much of the iron in Paso Robles
soil was of the oxidized, Fe3+ form. Towards the middle of the six-year
mission (a mission that was supposed to last only 90 days), large amounts of
pure [silica](/wiki/Silica "Silica") were found in the soil. The silica could
have come from the interaction of soil with acid vapors produced by volcanic
activity in the presence of water or from water in a hot spring
environment.[80]

After _Spirit_ stopped working scientists studied old data from the Miniature
Thermal Emission Spectrometer, or [Mini-TES](/wiki/Mini-TES "Mini-TES") and
confirmed the presence of large amounts of [carbonate](/wiki/Carbonate
"Carbonate")-rich rocks, which means that regions of the planet may have once
harbored water. The carbonates were discovered in an outcrop of rocks called
"Comanche."[81][82]

In summary, _Spirit_ found evidence of slight weathering on the plains of
Gusev, but no evidence that a lake was there. However, in the Columbia Hills
there was clear evidence for a moderate amount of aqueous weathering. The
evidence included sulfates and the minerals goethite and carbonates which only
form in the presence of water. It is believed that Gusev crater may have held
a lake long ago, but it has since been covered by igneous materials. All the
dust contains a magnetic component which was identified as magnetite with some
titanium. Furthermore, the thin coating of dust that covers everything on Mars
is the same in all parts of Mars.

### _Opportunity_ Landing Site, Meridiani
Planum[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mars_Exploration_Rover&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Opportunity Landing Site, Meridiani Planum")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/PIA17759-MarsOpportunityRover-
SelfPortrait-20140106.jpg/220px-PIA17759-MarsOpportunityRover-
SelfPortrait-20140106.jpg)](/wiki/File:PIA17759-MarsOpportunityRover-
SelfPortrait-20140106.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PIA17759-MarsOpportunityRover-SelfPortrait-20140106.jpg
"Enlarge")

Self-portrait of [_Opportunity_](/wiki/Opportunity_\(rover\) "Opportunity
\(rover\)") near [Endeavour Crater](/wiki/Endeavour_\(crater\) "Endeavour
\(crater\)") on the surface of [Mars](/wiki/Mars "Mars") (January 6, 2014).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/PIA21497capetrib.jpg/220px-
PIA21497capetrib.jpg)](/wiki/File:PIA21497capetrib.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PIA21497capetrib.jpg "Enlarge")

[Cape Tribulation](/wiki/Cape_Tribulation_\(Mars\) "Cape Tribulation
\(Mars\)") southern end, as seen in 2017 by Opportunity rover

The _Opportunity_ rover landed in a small crater, dubbed "Eagle", on the flat
plains of Meridiani. The plains of the landing site were characterized by the
presence of a large number of small [spherules](/wiki/Martian_spherules
"Martian spherules"), spherical [concretions](/wiki/Concretion "Concretion")
that were tagged "blueberries" by the science team, which were found both
loose on the surface, and also embedded in the rock. These proved to have a
high concentration of the mineral [hematite](/wiki/Hematite "Hematite"), and
showed the signature of being formed in an aqueous environment. The layered
bedrock revealed in the crater walls showed signs of being sedimentary in
nature, and compositional and microscopic-imagery analysis showed this to be
primarily with composition of [Jarosite](/wiki/Jarosite "Jarosite"), a ferrous
sulfate mineral that is characteristically an [evaporite](/wiki/Evaporite
"Evaporite") that is the residue from the evaporation of a salty pond or
sea.[83][84]

The mission has provided substantial evidence of past water activity on Mars.
In addition to investigating the "water hypothesis", _Opportunity_ has also
obtained astronomical observations and atmospheric data. The extended mission
took the rover across the plains to a series of larger craters in the south,
with the arrival at the edge of a 25-km diameter crater, Endeavour Crater,
eight years after landing. The orbital spectroscopy of this crater rim show
the signs of [phyllosilicate](/wiki/Phyllosilicate "Phyllosilicate") rocks,
indicative of older sedimentary deposits.
